title: 1. Introduction to TypeScript
explanation: TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that adds static types. This means you can declare the type of a variable, function parameter, or object property. The main benefit is catching errors during development (at compile time) rather than at runtime. All valid JavaScript code is also valid TypeScript code.
example:
let message: string = "Hello, TypeScript!";
// message = 123; // This would cause a compile-time error

title: 2. Basic Types
explanation: TypeScript provides several basic types that you can use to annotate your variables. These include `string`, `number`, `boolean`, `any` (opt-out of type checking), `unknown` (safer alternative to any), `void` (for functions that don't return a value), `null`, and `undefined`.

title: 3. Arrays and Tuples
explanation: You can define typed arrays in two ways: `type[]` or `Array<type>`. A tuple is a special type of array where the type of a fixed number of elements is known, but they don't have to be the same.

title: 4. Functions
explanation: TypeScript allows you to add types to the parameters and the return value of a function. This makes your functions more predictable and easier to use correctly.

title: 5. Interfaces
explanation: An interface is a way to define the shape of an object. It's like a contract for your code, ensuring that an object has a specific set of properties with specific types. Interfaces are a core part of TypeScript and are used extensively.

title: 6. Union Types
explanation: A union type allows a variable to be one of several types. You can define a union type using the pipe character `|`. This is useful when a value can be one of a few different, but specific, types.

title: 7. Type Aliases
explanation: Type aliases allow you to create a new name for a type. They don't create a new type, but rather a new name to refer to that type. They are useful for creating shorter or more descriptive names for complex types, like unions or objects.

title: 8. Classes
explanation: TypeScript supports object-oriented programming with classes, similar to languages like Java or C#. You can use features like constructors, properties, methods, inheritance, and access modifiers (`public`, `private`, `protected`).

title: 9. Generics
explanation: Generics provide a way to create reusable components that can work over a variety of types rather than a single one. This allows users to consume these components and use their own types. A common example is a generic array `Array<T>` where `T` can be any type.

title: 10. Enums
explanation: Enums allow you to define a set of named constants. Using enums can make it easier to document intent, or create a set of distinct cases. TypeScript provides both numeric and string-based enums.
